text: the death toll from wildfires in Maui
reaches at least 96 and in Niger coup
leaders have announced plans to
prosecute the country's deposed
president good morning I'm Windsor
Johnston with NPR news and here are
today's top stories catastrophic
wildfires burning in Maui have left a
trail of Destruction across the island
officials in Hawaii say an estimated 2
700 homes businesses and other
structures have been destroyed NPR's
Gabriel Spitzer reports the death toll
has risen to at least 96 as search and
rescue teams comb through the remains of
burned buildings Governor Josh Green
says a comprehensive review has begun
that will figure out how the fires
caught so many by surprise he says winds
gusted up to 81 miles per hour and
pushed the blaze about a mile a minute
through West Maui with temperatures
topping a thousand degrees because that
level of Destruction in a fire hurricane
something new to Us in this age of
global warming was the ultimate reason
that so many people perished Governor
green says the Federal Emergency
Management agency has more than 400
staff in Maui including administrator
Deanne Criswell he says they expect
another 35 people from FEMA's Urban
search and rescue team to arrive soon
along with 20 dogs
Gabriel Spitzer NPR news Maui the
largest public school district in
Kentucky is canceling two more days of
classes while it tries to fix its new
bus routes Louisville Public media's
Morgan Watkins report significant bus
delays created major problems for
students last week Jefferson County
Public Schools is trying to avoid a
repeat of last week's delays that led
some parents to call police over their
missing kids that's why the district
canceled classes last Thursday and
Friday and then canceled them again
school won't resume until at least this
Wednesday
superintendent Marty polio said Friday
that they will make improvements there
are still going to be challenges they're
going to be delays we're working in the
same system but it's going to be much
more efficient and our communication
will be much better with families and
schools and so we want to make sure we
get that right before we put the kids
back on a school bus again it's possible
more school days might be canceled this
week for NPR news I'm Morgan Watkins in
Louisville military leaders and Niger
have announced plans to prosecute the
deposed president Muhammad bazum after
overthrowing his democratically elected
government last month speaking through a
BBC interpreter Army spokesman ahmadu
abdramani says they've been Gathering
evidence against bazoom the Nigerian
government has so far gathered the
necessary elements of proof to prosecute
the deposed president and his local and
foreign accomplices before the competent
National and international bodies for
high treason and for undermining the
internal and external security of Niger
the announcement to charge by Zoom comes
just hours after coup leaders said they
were open to negotiations with leaders
of the West African Regional block
this is NPR news in Washington
